metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: JavaScript Hoisting
Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top.
content.html: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving declarations to the top.

content.text: JavaScript Declarations are Hoisted
In JavaScript, a variable can be declared after it has been used.
content.html: In JavaScript, a variable can be declared after it has been used.

content.text: In other words; a variable can be used before it has been declared.
content.html: In other words; a variable can be used before it has been declared.

content.text: Example 1 gives the same result as Example 2 :
content.html: Example 1 gives the same result as Example 2:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the elementvar x; // Declare x

syntax_highlighting.text:
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the elementvar x; // Declare x

content.code_html:
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x
elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x;                     // Display x in the element

var x; // Declare x

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the elementvar x; // Declare x

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x; // Declare x
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x
elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the element

syntax_highlighting.text:
var x; // Declare x
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x
elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the element

content.code_html:
var x; // Declare x
 x = 5; // Assign 5 to x

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x;                     // Display x in the element

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
var x; // Declare x
x = 5; // Assign 5 to x
elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element elem.innerHTML = x;                     
// Display x in the element

content.text: To understand this, you have to understand the term "hoisting".
content.html: To understand this, you have to understand the term "hoisting".

content.text: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving all declarations to the top of the current scope (to the top of the current script or the current function).
content.html: Hoisting is JavaScript's default behavior of moving all declarations to the top of the current scope (to the top of the current script or the current function).

content.text: The let and const Keywords
Variables defined with let and const are hoisted to the top of the block, but not initialized .
content.html: Variables defined with let and const are hoisted to the top of the block, but not initialized.

content.text: Meaning: The block of code is aware of the variable, but it cannot be used until it has been declared.
content.html: Meaning: The block of code is aware of the variable, but it cannot be used until it has been declared.

content.text: Using a let variable before it is declared will result in a ReferenceError .
content.html: Using a let variable before it is declared will result in a ReferenceError.

content.text: The variable is in a "temporal dead zone" from the start of the block until it is declared:
content.html: The variable is in a "temporal dead zone" from the start of the block until it is declared:

content.code_html:
carName = "Volvo";
let carName;

content.text: Using a const variable before it is declared, is a syntax error, so the code will simply not run.
content.html: Using a const variable before it is declared, is a syntax error, so the code will simply not run.

content.code_html:
carName = "Volvo";
const carName;

content.text: Read more about let and const in JS Let / Const .
content.html: Read more about let and const in JS Let / Const.

content.text: JavaScript Initializations are Not Hoisted
JavaScript only hoists declarations, not initializations.
content.html: JavaScript only hoists declarations, not initializations.

content.text: Example 1 does not give the same result as Example 2 :
content.html: Example 1 does not give the same result as Example 2:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x = 5; // Initialize xvar y = 7; // Initialize yelem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

content.code:
var x = 5; // Initialize xvar y = 7; // Initialize yelem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

syntax_highlighting.text:
var x = 5; // Initialize xvar y = 7; // Initialize yelem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

content.code_html:
var x = 5; // Initialize x
var y = 7; // Initialize y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

var y = 7; // Initialize y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

var y = 7; // Initialize y

var y = 7; // Initialize y

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

var y = 7; // Initialize y

content.text: Does it make sense that y is undefined in the last example?
content.html: Does it make sense that y is undefined in the last example?

content.text: This is because only the declaration (var y), not the initialization (=7) is hoisted to the top.
content.html: This is because only the declaration (var y), not the initialization (=7) is hoisted to the top.

content.text: Because of hoisting, y has been declared before it is used, but because initializations are not hoisted, the value of y is undefined.
content.html: Because of hoisting, y has been declared before it is used, but because initializations are not hoisted, the value of y is undefined.

content.text: Example 2 is the same as writing:
content.html: Example 2 is the same as writing:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
var x = 5; // Initialize x
var y;     // Declare y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

y = 7;    // Assign 7 to y

content.code:

var y;     // Declare y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

y = 7;    // Assign 7 to y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

 var y;     // Declare y
elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y
y = 7;    // Assign 7 to y

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

var y;     // Declare y

elem = document.getElementById("demo"); // Find an element 
elem.innerHTML = x + " " + y;           // Display x and y

y = 7;    // Assign 7 to y

content.text: Declare Your Variables At the Top !
Hoisting is (to many developers) an unknown or overlooked behavior of JavaScript.
content.html: Hoisting is (to many developers) an unknown or overlooked behavior of JavaScript.

content.text: If a developer doesn't understand hoisting, programs may contain bugs (errors).
content.html: If a developer doesn't understand hoisting, programs may contain bugs (errors).

content.text: To avoid bugs, always declare all variables at the beginning of every scope.
content.html: To avoid bugs, always declare all variables at the beginning of every scope.

content.text: Since this is how JavaScript interprets the code, it is always a good rule.
content.html: Since this is how JavaScript interprets the code, it is always a good rule.

content.text: JavaScript in strict mode does not allow variables to be used if they are not declared. Study "use strict" in the next chapter.
content.html:
JavaScript in strict mode does not allow variables to be used if they are not declared.
Study "use strict" in the next chapter.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider the following code: x = 5; alert(x); var x; What will be the alerted result?
content.html:
Consider the following code:
x = 5;
alert(x);
var x;
What will be the alerted result?
